abstract: The nation’s employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. Not since December 1974, toward the end of a severe recession, have so many jobs disappeared in a single month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent, up just two-tenths of a percentage point from October in part because it does not include all those too discouraged to look for work any longer or those working fewer hours than they would like. The number of part-time workers who want full-time work rose sharply, to 7.3 million, up 62.2 percent from November of last year.

lead_paragraph: The nation’s employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. Not since December 1974, toward the end of a severe recession, have so many jobs disappeared in a single month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent, up just two-tenths of a percentage point from October in part because it does not include all those too discouraged to look for work any longer or those working fewer hours than they would like. The number of part-time workers who want full-time work rose sharply, to 7.3 million, up 62.2 percent from November of last year.
